"myself Details Story Dictionary 俺 myself Heisig's The key word refers to a very familiar way of referring to oneself, typically used by men. Its component elements: person . . . St. Bernard . . . eel. Koohii #1 I did it all by myself! Mr T stands there proud as holding a moray eel in his hand. He´s brought down terrorist organisations, drug syndicates, but gets all worked up when catching a fish... what a guy. Koohii #2 As astridtops mentions, this is ""Ore"". In Japanese r = l, so could write it ""Ole"". So picture a bullfight with person as the matador and a dachshund replacing the bull. The crowd keep shouting ""Ole! (Ore)"". Primitives myself, person, dachshund, large, St. Bernard, eel, sun, day 俺(おれ): I (ego) (boastful first-person pronoun) Kunyomi: おれ、われ Onyomi: エン Lesson: 27 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: Compounds: 俺 (おれ)"	"myself 俺 画数10 1091 Details Story Dictionary 俺 myself Heisig's The key word refers to a very familiar way of referring to oneself, typically used by men. "long time Details Story Dictionary 久 long time Heisig's This character uses the diagonal sweep of the second stroke to double up for bound up and a person. Think of a mummy, and the key word will not be far behind. Koohii #1 Note: this is the ひさ in ひさしぶり . Long time no see mummy! (A bound up person). Koohii #2 This is a picture of a person bowing ""long time no see!"". Primitives long time, bound up, person, mummy 久しい(ひさしい): long, long-continued, old (story) 久し振り(ひさしぶり): after a long time 永久(えいきゅう): eternity, perpetuity, immortality 久しぶり(ひさしぶり): after a long time, long time (no see) Kunyomi: ひさ.しい Onyomi: キュウ、ク Lesson: 27 Jouyou: 5 JLPT Level: 2 Compounds: 永久 (えいきゅう), 持久 (じきゅう), 耐久 (たいきゅう), 久しい (ひさ.しい)"	"long time 久 画数3 1092 Details Story Dictionary 久 long time Heisig's This character uses the diagonal sweep of the second stroke to double up for bound up and a person. furrow Details Story Dictionary 畝 furrow Heisig's Think of the three kinds of furrows shown here in this character - a top hat's rim, a rice field's ridges, and the wrinkles that show you've been around a long time. So he furrows his brain. [trigger: furrow your brain]. inside Details Story Dictionary 内 inside Heisig's Person . . . belt. Note that we cannot use the primitive meaning of hood here because the person runs THROUGH the element, not under it. Koohii #1 Mr. T´s new belt is huge! When he´s inside it, his feet no longer touch the ground! Koohii #2 How is a person ever supposed to get inside that girl when she´s wearing such a huge chastity belt? I guess that´s kinda the point, eh? "third class Details Story Dictionary 丙 third class Heisig's Those no-frills flights the airlines offer to attract customers should help create an image from ceiling . . . person . . . belt. The kanji meaning ""inside"" should not be used because of its proximity to the element for ""in."" Koohii #1 In this third class flight, the seatbelts are so bad that with the slightest turbulence all the persons hit the ceiling. (it´s almost pictographic here!). Koohii #2 But third class is so small Mr. T´s head hits the celing. Primitives third class, one, ceiling, inside, person, belt Kunyomi: ひのえ Onyomi: ヘイ Lesson: 27 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:"	"third class 丙 画数5 1096 Details Story Dictionary 丙 third class Heisig's Those no-frills flights the airlines offer to attract customers should help create an image from ceiling . . . person . . . belt. "meat Details Story Dictionary 肉 meat Heisig's Let this doubling of one of the elements for ""inside"" yield the sense of ""insides"" to approach the key word, meat. The abbreviated form of this character gave us the primitive meaning of flesh or part of the body for the kanji 月. Koohii #1 Here we are looking at an x-ray of a cannibal whose insides are full on people-meat. Koohii #2 A person´s inside - fleshy, raw, pink, meat. Koohii #2 There are two assembly lines at the umbrella factory. One is responsible for making the top of the umbrella, and the other for making the handle. "monme Details Story Dictionary 匁 monme Heisig's This character obliges us once again to make use of a Japanese key word for want of an English equivalent. It refers to an old unit of weight, equal to about 3.75 grams. The word is only slightly more useful in modern Japanese than cubits and kites are in modern English. Its primitives, if you look closely, are: bound up . . . arm. Koohii #1 Dude! What happened to your arm! It´s all bound up! ""Yeah man, it´s a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!"". Koohii #2 Dude! What happened to your arm! It´s all bound up! ""Yeah man, it´s a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!"" ""You´ll never be able to use your dagger now!"" (adapted from ergerg). Primitives monme, bound up, tucked under the arm Kunyomi: もんめ、め Onyomi: Lesson: 28 Jouyou: Names JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 匁 (もんめ)"	"monme 匁 画数4 1104 Details Story Dictionary 匁 monme Heisig's This character obliges us once again to make use of a Japanese key word for want of an English equivalent. It refers to an old unit of weight, equal to about 3.75 grams. The word is only slightly more useful in modern Japanese than cubits and kites are in modern English. Its primitives, if you look closely, are: bound up . . . arm. Koohii #1 Dude! What happened to your arm! It´s all bound up! ""Yeah man, it´s a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!"". Koohii #2 Dude! What happened to your arm! It´s all bound up! ""Yeah man, it´s a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!"" ""You´ll never be able to use your dagger now!"" (adapted from ergerg). Primitives monme, bound up, tucked under the arm Kunyomi: もんめ、め Onyomi: Lesson: 28 Jouyou: Names JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 匁 (もんめ)"
"by means of Details Story Dictionary 以 by means of My Story Picture a person dragging a plow behind, and the drop of sweat which falls from his brow as he does his work. Think of him (or her, for that matter) making a living “by means of the sweat of their brows.” Koohii #1 A man earns his living by means of the plow. I imagine a sweating man dragging a bronze-age ""ard"" behind him as he plows his field himself, too poor to afford an ox. Koohii #2 Mr T now makes a living by means of a plow/hoe and the sweat he puts into it. Primitives by means of, plow, drop, person 以て(もって): with, by, by means of, because, in view of 以外(いがい): except for, other than 以後(いご): from now on, thereafter 以降(いこう): on and after, hereafter, thereafter 以前(いぜん): ago, since, before, previous 以来(いらい): since, henceforth 以下(いか): ~ or less than?not more than 以上(いじょう): more than, over 以内(いない): within Kunyomi: もっ.て Onyomi: イ Lesson: 28 Jouyou: 4 JLPT Level: 4 Compounds:"	"by means of 以 画数5 1105 Details Story Dictionary 以 by means of My Story Picture a person dragging a plow behind, and the drop of sweat which falls from his brow as he does his work. Koohii #2 Mr T now makes a living by means of a plow/hoe and the sweat he puts into it. similar Details Story Dictionary 似 similar My Story [Person + By means of{以}] A *PERSON* can become quite SIMILAR to someone else *BY MEANS OF* plastic surgery. Koohii #1 Mr. T finds that living by means of dragging a plow is similar to slavery. Koohii #2 A Mr T impersonator is becoming similarer (more like) by means of plastic surgery. The process is painful and his face is all bound up in bandages as the surgery heals. Primitives becoming, similar, person, by means of, plow, drop, person 似通う(にかよう): to resemble closely 類似(るいじ): analogous 似合う(にあう): suit, match, become, be like 真似(まね): mimicry, imitation, behavior, pretense 真似る(まねる): mimic, imitate 似る(にる): look like Kunyomi: に.る、ひ.る Onyomi: ジ Lesson: 28 Jouyou: 5 JLPT Level: 3 Compounds: 似る (に.る)	similar 似 画数7 1106 Details Story Dictionary 似 similar My Story [Person + By means of{以}] A *PERSON* can become quite SIMILAR to someone else *BY MEANS OF* plastic surgery. The process is painful and his face is all bound up in bandages as the surgery heals. join Details Story Dictionary 併 join Heisig's The sense of the key word is one of joining things together that were previously separate. Its elements: person . . . puzzle. Koohii #1 Mr. T furiously works a puzzle in an attempt to join Mensa, the high-IQ society. Koohii #2 Why do I gotta join these two puzzle pieces? I ain´t got time for joining no jigsaw-jabba! Mr. T apparently gets a severe case of crankypants when doing puzzles. "Shinto shrine Details Story Dictionary 宮 Shinto shrine Heisig's Way back in lesson 2 we learned the character for spine. The two other characters in which it is used we can now learn together in this and the following frame. Here a Shinto shrine is composed of house and spine. Koohii #1 This Shinto shrine is built with human spines. Have you ever seen the ossuary in Sedlec, near Kutna Hora in Czech Republic ? It is a small church entirely decorated with human bones. Do a web search for ""sedlec ossuary"", it´s quite a sight. Koohii #2 A friend of mine made up a rhyme for this one: ""house with a spine, Shinto shrine""! Primitives shinto shrine, house, spine, mouth, drop, mouth2 お宮(おみや): Shinto shrine 宮殿(きゅうでん): palace Kunyomi: みや Onyomi: キュウ、グウ、ク、クウ Lesson: 28 Jouyou: 3 JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 宮殿 (きゅうでん), 宮廷 (きゅうてい), 離宮 (りきゅう), 宮 (みや)"	"Shinto shrine 宮 画数10 1110 Details Story Dictionary 宮 Shinto shrine Heisig's Way back in lesson 2 we learned the character for spine. "occupation Details Story Dictionary 営 occupation Heisig's Schoolhouse . . . spine. Koohii #1 The schoolhouse is the backbone of a foundation that will allow you to find a good occupation. Koohii #2 During the German occupation, this Nazi officer´s occupation was to manage schools that were requisitioned for training the children of the Aryan race to stand proud with an erect spine (mnemonic : ""the occupation´s spine schools""). Kanji meanings : to manage, to conduct (business), and also ""barracks; camp; encapment"". This story should help avoid confusion with post (#824) and employ (#1083). The military occupation theme hints to the secondary meaning, e.g. 営倉 ""detention barracks"". Primitives occupation, schoolhouse, owl, crown, spine, mouth, drop, mouth2 営む(いとなむ): to carry on (e.g. in ceremony), to run a business 運営(うんえい): management, administration, operation 営業(えいぎょう): business, trade, sales, operations 経営(けいえい): management, administration Kunyomi: いとな.む、いとな.み Onyomi: エイ Lesson: 28 Jouyou: 5 JLPT Level: 2 Compounds: 営む (いとな.む)"	"occupation 営 画数12 1111 Details Story Dictionary 営 occupation Heisig's Schoolhouse . . . spine. Koohii #1 The schoolhouse is the backbone of a foundation that will allow you to find a good occupation. Koohii #2 During the German occupation, this Nazi officer´s occupation was to manage schools that were requisitioned for training the children of the Aryan race to stand proud with an erect spine (mnemonic : ""the occupation´s spine schools""). Kanji meanings : to manage, to conduct (business), and also ""barracks; camp; encapment"". This story should help avoid confusion with post (#824) and employ (#1083). The military occupation theme hints to the secondary meaning, e.g. 営倉 ""detention barracks"". Primitives occupation, schoolhouse, owl, crown, spine, mouth, drop, mouth2 営む(いとなむ): to carry on (e.g. in ceremony), to run a business 運営(うんえい): management, administration, operation 営業(えいぎょう): business, trade, sales, operations 経営(けいえい): management, administration Kunyomi: いとな.む、いとな.み Onyomi: エイ Lesson: 28 Jouyou: 5 JLPT Level: 2 Compounds: 営む (いとな.む)"
"virtuous Details Story Dictionary 善 virtuous Heisig's Sheep . . . horns . . . mouth. Pay special attention to the writing of this character. Koohii #1 Imagine a priest´s teaching: ""To achieve virtue one must first submit himself as a sheep to God´s flock, rejecting the horns of Satan and resisting the mouth of Hell. Koohii #2 To be virtuous, a good rule to follow is to put your sheepishness (discretion) over your horns (anger) before using your mouth. In other words, ""discretion is the better part of virtue"". Primitives virtuous, sheep, horns, mouth 最善(さいぜん): the very best 親善(しんぜん): friendship 善良(ぜんりょう): goodness, excellence, virtue 善し悪し(よしあし): good or bad, merits or demerits, quality, suitability 改善(かいぜん): betterment, improvement, incremental and continuous improvement 善(ぜん): good, goodness, right, virtue Kunyomi: よ.い、い.い、よ.く、よし.とする Onyomi: ゼン Lesson: 28 Jouyou: 6 JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 善い (よ.い)"	"virtuous 善 画数12 1112 Details Story Dictionary 善 virtuous Heisig's Sheep . . . horns . . . mouth. Pay special attention to the writing of this character. Koohii #1 Imagine a priest´s teaching: ""To achieve virtue one must first submit himself as a sheep to God´s flock, rejecting the horns of Satan and resisting the mouth of Hell. Koohii #2 To be virtuous, a good rule to follow is to put your sheepishness (discretion) over your horns (anger) before using your mouth. In other words, ""discretion is the better part of virtue"". Primitives virtuous, sheep, horns, mouth 最善(さいぜん): the very best 親善(しんぜん): friendship 善良(ぜんりょう): goodness, excellence, virtue 善し悪し(よしあし): good or bad, merits or demerits, quality, suitability 改善(かいぜん): betterment, improvement, incremental and continuous improvement 善(ぜん): good, goodness, right, virtue Kunyomi: よ.い、い.い、よ.く、よし.とする Onyomi: ゼン Lesson: 28 Jouyou: 6 JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 善い (よ.い)"
dining tray Details Story Dictionary 膳 dining tray Heisig's Flesh . . . virtuous. Koohii #1 Some people insist that the serving maids who bring in the dining trays are especially virtuous and never let any man touch their flesh. Koohii #2 The virtuous vegan will not touch this dining tray because it has had a piece of meat on it. Primitives dining tray, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, virtuous, sheep, horns, mouth 膳(ぜん): (small) table, tray, meal Kunyomi: かしわ、すす.める、そな.える Onyomi: ゼン、セン Lesson: 28 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: Compounds:	dining tray 膳 画数16 1113 Details Story Dictionary 膳 dining tray Heisig's Flesh . . . virtuous. Koohii #1 Some people insist that the serving maids who bring in the dining trays are especially virtuous and never let any man touch their flesh. Koohii #2 The virtuous vegan will not touch this dining tray because it has had a piece of meat on it. Primitives dining tray, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, virtuous, sheep, horns, mouth 膳(ぜん): (small) table, tray, meal Kunyomi: かしわ、すす.める、そな.える Onyomi: ゼン、セン Lesson: 28 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: Compounds:
year Details Story Dictionary 年 year Heisig's In an odd fashion, the kanji for year joins together the element for horse, on the top, and the right half of the element for sunglasses. Think of it as a horse wearing sunglasses with one of the lenses popped out. We will use this latter image again, so learn it now and save yourself the trouble later. Koohii #1 A horse wears a pair of sunglasses with one lens popped out after a particularly raucous celebration to ring in the New Year. Koohii #2 A horse wears a monocle for New Years to appear dignified for the year of the horse. ――one lens = monocle, you will encounter this again in kanji like descend (#1308). Primitives year, sign of the horse, sunglasses 一昨年(おととし): year before last 同い年(おないどし): of the same age 元年(がんねん): first year (of a specific reign) 成年(せいねん): majority, adult age 定年(ていねん): retirement age 年頃(としごろ): age, marriageable age, age of puberty, adolescence, for some years 年寄り(としより): old people, the aged 年鑑(ねんかん): yearbook 年号(ねんごう): name of an era, year number 年生(ねんせい): pupil in .... year, student in .... year 年長(ねんちょう): seniority 年輪(ねんりん): annual tree ring 一昨年(いっさくねん): year before last 学年(がくねん): year in school, grade in school 少年(しょうねん): boys, juveniles 青少年(せいしょうねん): youth, young person 青年(せいねん): youth, young man 生年月日(せいねんがっぴ): birth date 中年(ちゅうねん): middle-aged 年月(としつき): months and years 年間(ねんかん): year (interval of time) 年月(ねんげつ): months and years 年中(ねんじゅう): whole year, always, everyday 年代(ねんだい): age, era, period, date 年度(ねんど): year, fiscal year, school year, term 年齢(ねんれい): age, years 年(とし): year 去年(きょねん): last year 今年(ことし): this year 再来年(さらいねん): year after next 万年筆(まんねんひつ): fountain pen 来年(らいねん): next year Kunyomi: とし Onyomi: ネン Lesson: 28 Jouyou: 1 JLPT Level: 5 Compounds: 年 (とし)	year 年 画数6 1114 Details Story Dictionary 年 year Heisig's In an odd fashion, the kanji for year joins together the element for horse, on the top, and the right half of the element for sunglasses. Think of it as a horse wearing sunglasses with one of the lenses popped out. We will use this latter image again, so learn it now and save yourself the trouble later. Koohii #1 A horse wears a pair of sunglasses with one lens popped out after a particularly raucous celebration to ring in the New Year. Koohii #2 A horse wears a monocle for New Years to appear dignified for the year of the horse. ――one lens = monocle, you will encounter this again in kanji like descend (#1308). Primitives year, sign of the horse, sunglasses 一昨年(おととし): year before last 同い年(おないどし): of the same age 元年(がんねん): first year (of a specific reign) 成年(せいねん): majority, adult age 定年(ていねん): retirement age 年頃(としごろ): age, marriageable age, age of puberty, adolescence, for some years 年寄り(としより): old people, the aged 年鑑(ねんかん): yearbook 年号(ねんごう): name of an era, year number 年生(ねんせい): pupil in .... year, student in .... year 年長(ねんちょう): seniority 年輪(ねんりん): annual tree ring 一昨年(いっさくねん): year before last 学年(がくねん): year in school, grade in school 少年(しょうねん): boys, juveniles 青少年(せいしょうねん): youth, young person 青年(せいねん): youth, young man 生年月日(せいねんがっぴ): birth date 中年(ちゅうねん): middle-aged 年月(としつき): months and years 年間(ねんかん): year (interval of time) 年月(ねんげつ): months and years 年中(ねんじゅう): whole year, always, everyday 年代(ねんだい): age, era, period, date 年度(ねんど): year, fiscal year, school year, term 年齢(ねんれい): age, years 年(とし): year 去年(きょねん): last year 今年(ことし): this year 再来年(さらいねん): year after next 万年筆(まんねんひつ): fountain pen 来年(らいねん): next year Kunyomi: とし Onyomi: ネン Lesson: 28 Jouyou: 1 JLPT Level: 5 Compounds: 年 (とし)
"night Details Story Dictionary 夜 night Heisig's First of all, be sure not to confuse the connotations of night with those of evening (Frame 114) and nightbreak (Frame 30). Its elements: top hat . . . person . . . walking legs . . . drop. Koohii #1 Actually, the lower-right primitive isn´t quite ""walking legs."" It´s a little more like ""evening"" with an extra stroke across it (look up the stroke order). So, it helps me to see this kanji for night as: evening plus an extra stroke representing the tuxedo tails to match the top hat which my special person is wearing out on the town... Koohii #2 Here we have Mister T sleepwalking, wearing a top hat as if he was the ambassador of the night, walking, and walking and walking on his tired walking legs, until he drops (back into his bed). Primitives night, top hat, person, walking legs, drop 日夜(にちや): day and night, always 夜行(やぎょう): walking around at night, night train, night travel 夜具(やぐ): bedding 夜中(やちゅう): all night, the whole night 夜更かし(よふかし): staying up late, keeping late hours, sitting up late at night, nighthawk 夜更け(よふけ): late at night 深夜(しんや): late at night 徹夜(てつや): all night, all-night vigil, sleepless night 夜間(やかん): at night, nighttime 夜行(やこう): walking around at night, night train, night travel 夜(よ): night 夜明け(よあけ): dawn, daybreak 夜中(よなか): all night, the whole night 今夜(こんや): tonight 夜(よる): evening, night Kunyomi: よ、よる Onyomi: ヤ Lesson: 28 Jouyou: 2 JLPT Level: 4 Compounds: 夜 (よ), 夜 (よる)"	"night 夜 画数8 1115 Details Story Dictionary 夜 night Heisig's First of all, be sure not to confuse the connotations of night with those of evening (Frame 114) and nightbreak (Frame 30). fluid Details Story Dictionary 液 fluid Heisig's Water . . . night. Koohii #1 A wet dream........water fluid that comes out at night.... Koohii #2 I imagined some kind of liquid (water) that was discovered on another planet. It solidifes during the day, and becomes fluid only at night, in the absence of light. The question is, could any lifeforms thrive in there ? Primitives fluid, water, water droplets, water pistol, night, top hat, person, walking legs, drop 液(えき): liquid, fluid 溶液(ようえき): solution (liquid) 液体(えきたい): liquid, fluid 血液(けつえき): blood Kunyomi: Onyomi: エキ Lesson: 28 Jouyou: 5 JLPT Level: 2 Compounds:	fluid 液 画数11 1116 Details Story Dictionary 液 fluid Heisig's Water . . . night. It´s Ms. Piggy sitting on top of a mound of soil in her crown. Koohii #2 The crowned sow (we met her in overpowering) is standing atop her little mound of earth - hillock - the undisputed champeen of all the pigsty. "cash Details Story Dictionary 幣 cash Heisig's Shredder . . . towel. Koohii #1 A counterfeiter is using a shredder to shred a towel in order to print up some cash (he needs some rag paper) . Koohii #2 In order to create some cash, first you feed a towel through a shredder to get the raw materials. (""Paper"" money isn´t plain paper; it´s mostly linen.). abuse Details Story Dictionary 弊 abuse Heisig's Shredder . . . two hands. Koohii #1 The Bush administration taskmasters hid their abuse of power by shredding documents as fast as they could using both hands....　　　　　RTK2: 　ヘイ　弊害　へいがい(abuse)...　　　Pure Group:　幣1041. Koohii #2 You’ve heard of Edward Scissor hands? Well this is Medward Shredder Hands. Instead of nicely trimming your shrubs, he uses his TWO SHREDDER equipped HANDS to ABUSE your plants by shredding them into wood chips. Primitives abuse, shredder, small, little, belt, taskmaster, two hands Kunyomi: Onyomi: ヘイ Lesson: 28 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:	abuse 弊 画数15 1120 Details Story Dictionary 弊 abuse Heisig's Shredder . . . two hands. yell Details Story Dictionary 喚 yell Heisig's The mouth on the left is obvious. The rest is harder. Try this: four St. Bernard dogs bound up in a bunch. Together they should supply a clear enough portrait of a yell, provided you are careful to see all four of them. Note how the final stroke of the four is supplied by the long horizontal stroke of the St .Bernard. Koohii #1 Think yelp when you hear yell to help dinstinguish this from shout (1508). I think of the sounds that would come from the mouths of the 4 dogs if they were bound up together. I´m imagining lots of yelping. Koohii #2 Yell? You mean, Old Yeller. Here, we see four St Bernard dogs all yelling for a chance to play a part in Old Yeller. They´re so loud that you have to bound them, and their mouths, up. Primitives yell, mouth, bound up, four, large, St. Bernard Kunyomi: わめ.く Onyomi: カン Lesson: 28 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:	yell 喚 画数12 1121 Details Story Dictionary 喚 yell Heisig's The mouth on the left is obvious. interchange Details Story Dictionary 換 interchange My Story My Nigga *Mo* CAN exchange (interchange) his hand for *four* *big* *fish hooks* (FYI I am some kind of rejected Bond villain) Koohii #1 After months of practice, you finally managed to teach a nice trick to your sled-pulling four bound up St. Bernard dogs: one snap of your fingers and they interchange their positions. Koohii #2 On the snap of your fingers, the four St. Bernard dogs bound up interchange places. Primitives interchange, finger, fingers, bound up, four, large, St. Bernard 換える(かえる): to exchange, to interchange, to substitute, to replace 換算(かんさん): conversion, change, exchange 転換(てんかん): convert, divert 乗り換え(のりかえ): transfer (trains buses etc.) 換気(かんき): ventilation 交換(こうかん): exchange, interchange, reciprocity, barter, substitution 乗換(のりかえ): transfer (trains, buses, etc.) 乗り換える(のりかえる): transfer Kunyomi: か.える、-か.える、か.わる Onyomi: カン Lesson: 28 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 2 Compounds: 換える (か.える), 換わる (か.わる)	interchange 換 画数12 1122 Details Story Dictionary 換 interchange My Story My Nigga *Mo* CAN exchange (interchange) his hand for *four* *big* *fish hooks* (FYI I am some kind of rejected Bond villain) Koohii #1 After months of practice, you finally managed to teach a nice trick to your sled-pulling four bound up St. Bernard dogs: one snap of your fingers and they interchange their positions. "dissolve Details Story Dictionary 融 dissolve Heisig's Ceiling . . . mouth . . . hood . . . human legs . . . spike . . . insect. This is the maximum number of elements to appear in any story in the book. Koohii #1 I have created the element ""old camera"" out of the left side of the kanji: from the subject´s point of view, the light is captured by one mouth (the lens). The photographer is under a big hood, we only see his legs, and he is holding a spike in his right hand, which is the shutter release. Now, at the time the photographer takes the photo, a little insect is flying near the flash. The flash is so powerful that the insect is burnt and dissolves in the air. Koohii #2 I´ve seen this crazy thing with only one mouth that can dissolve up to 4 nails and an insect at the same time. Sweet! (It´s a venus flytrap, btw). Primitives dissolve, tripod, one, ceiling, mouth, hood, human legs, street, nail, spike, insect 融資(ゆうし): financing, loan 融通(ゆうずう): lending (money), accommodation, adaptability, versatility, finance 金融(きんゆう): monetary circulation, credit situation Kunyomi: と.ける、と.かす Onyomi: ユウ Lesson: 28 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:"	"dissolve 融 画数16 1123 Details Story Dictionary 融 dissolve Heisig's Ceiling . . . mouth . . . hood . . . human legs . . . spike . . . insect. rotation Details Story Dictionary 旋 rotation Heisig's A banner . . . a zoo. Hint: think of a merry-go-round. Koohii #1 A merry-go-round with a big banner on top and below a veritable zoo of bakelite animals on poles in perpertual rotation accompanied by silly music. Giraffes, elephants, zebras, rhinos... Koohii #2 Don´t confuse with revolve or axis! Think of rotation as a rotation of animals in the zoo - some are on display (in rotation), some are in cages in the back (out of rotation). The ones currently in rotation (on display) are advertised with a large banner. Primitives rotation, banner, direction, compass, direction, reclining, lying down, zoo, critters Kunyomi: Onyomi: セン Lesson: 29 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:	rotation 旋 画数11 1125 Details Story Dictionary 旋 rotation Heisig's A banner . . . a zoo. "play Details Story Dictionary 遊 play Heisig's Banners . . . children . . . road. Koohii #1 The BANNER warns that CHILDREN PLAY on the ROAD. Koohii #2 There is always a stupid banner talking about children at play near the road. They mean ""drive slowly"", but it sounds like its slow(stupid) children that are at play. "trip Details Story Dictionary 旅 trip My Story When we go on a trip in that *direction*, we bring *a rifle* to shoot *hitchhikers*. Koohii #1 The boat starts to leave on it´s trip across the Atlantic. Underneath a huge banner that spans the width of the ship and says ""Bon Voyage"", the people wave their rags signalling a safe journey for all on board the Titanic. Koohii #2 After a long long trip, what once was a proud beautiful banner, we had nothing more than a simple rag remaining. Primitives trip, banner, direction, compass, direction, reclining, lying down, Carol in rags, person, rag 旅客(りょかく): passenger (transport) 旅券(りょけん): passport 旅(たび): travel, trip, journey 旅館(りょかん): Japanese inn 旅行(りょこう): travel, trip Kunyomi: たび Onyomi: リョ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: 3 JLPT Level: 4 Compounds: 旅 (たび)"	"trip 旅 画数10 1127 Details Story Dictionary 旅 trip My Story When we go on a trip in that *direction*, we bring *a rifle* to shoot *hitchhikers*. Koohii #2 After a long long trip, what once was a proud beautiful banner, we had nothing more than a simple rag remaining. Primitives trip, banner, direction, compass, direction, reclining, lying down, Carol in rags, person, rag 旅客(りょかく): passenger (transport) 旅券(りょけん): passport 旅(たび): travel, trip, journey 旅館(りょかん): Japanese inn 旅行(りょこう): travel, trip Kunyomi: たび Onyomi: リョ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: 3 JLPT Level: 4 Compounds: 旅 (たび)"
"not Details Story Dictionary 勿 not Heisig's First take the primitive meaning of this character: knot. Think of it as the piglet minus its body (the horizontal stroke), that is, the curly tail that looks like a knot. As an exception, we will use the homonym to remember the abstract key word, not. Koohii #1 This kanji is NOT a piglett. Koohii #2 The butcher is standing over the piglet. ""This is a piglet...(cuts of head)...NOT!"". Primitives not, knot, piglet’s tail 勿論(もちろん): of course, certainly, naturally Kunyomi: なか.れ、なし Onyomi: モチ、ブツ、ボツ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: Names JLPT Level: Compounds:"	"not 勿 画数4 1128 Details Story Dictionary 勿 not Heisig's First take the primitive meaning of this character: knot. Koohii #1 This kanji is NOT a piglett. Koohii #2 The butcher is standing over the piglet. ""This is a piglet...(cuts of head)...NOT!"". "thing Details Story Dictionary 物 thing Heisig's Cow . . . knot. Koohii #1 The cow´s ""thing"" is tied in a knot! ouch. Koohii #2 A cow is not a thing. Its an animal. If you study japanese you know that living beings and things are discerned from each other with the verbs iru and aru. Primitives thing, cow, knot, piglet’s tail 獲物(えもの): game, spoils, trophy 織物(おりもの): textile, fabric 贋物(がんぶつ): imitation, counterfeit, forgery, sham 禁物(きんもつ): taboo, forbidden thing 作物(さくぶつ): literary work 産物(さんぶつ): product, result, fruit 私物(しぶつ): private property, personal effects 出来物(できもの): able man, tumour, growth, boil, ulcer, abcess, rash, pimple 物議(ぶつぎ): public discussion (criticism) 物資(ぶっし): goods, materials 物体(ぶったい): body, object 干し物(ほしもの): dried washing (clothes) 見せ物(みせもの): show, exhibition 物置き(ものおき): storeroom 物好き(ものずき): curiosity 物足りない(ものたりない): unsatisfied, unsatisfactory 編物(あみもの): knitting, web 生き物(いきもの): animal 入れ物(いれもの): container, case, receptacle 落し物(おとしもの): lost property 貨物(かもつ): cargo, freight, money or assets 鉱物(こうぶつ): mineral 穀物(こくもつ): grain, cereal, corn 作物(さくもつ): literary work 実物(じつぶつ): real thing, original 植物(しょくぶつ): plant, vegetation 食物(しょくもつ): food, foodstuff 書物(しょもつ): books 人物(じんぶつ): character, personality, person, man, personage, talented man 生物(せいぶつ): living things, creature 瀬戸物(せともの): earthenware, crockery, china 農産物(のうさんぶつ): agricultural produce 博物館(はくぶつかん): museum 物価(ぶっか): prices of commodities, prices (in general), cost-of-living 物質(ぶっしつ): material, substance 物騒(ぶっそう): dangerous, disturbed, insecure 物理(ぶつり): physics 本物(ほんもの): genuine article 名物(めいぶつ): famous product, speciality 物置(ものおき): storage room 物音(ものおと): sounds 物語(ものがたり): tale, story, legend 物語る(ものがたる): tell, indicate 物事(ものごと): things, everything 物差し(ものさし): ruler, measure 物凄い(ものすごい): earth-shattering, staggering, to a very great extent 贈り物(おくりもの): gift 着物(きもの): Japanese traditional dress 見物(けんぶつ): sightseeing, see, look at 品物(しなもの): article, goods 動物園(どうぶつえん): zoo 乗り物(のりもの): vehicle, vessel 忘れ物(わすれもの): a thing left behind 買い物(かいもの): shopping 果物(くだもの): fruit 建物(たてもの): building 食べ物(たべもの): food 動物(どうぶつ): animal 荷物(にもつ): baggage, luggage 飲み物(のみもの): drink, beverage 物(もの): thing, object Kunyomi: もの、もの- Onyomi: ブツ、モツ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: 3 JLPT Level: 4 Compounds: 物質 (ぶっしつ), 人物 (じんぶつ), 動物 (どうぶつ), 物 (もの)"	"thing 物 画数8 1129 Details Story Dictionary 物 thing Heisig's Cow . . . knot. easy Details Story Dictionary 易 easy My Story The *sun* is an easy *thing* to see. Koohii #1 The sun is not an easy place to get to. Koohii #2 Under the sun, it is easy to untie a knot. Under a pitch-dark sky, it is knot so easy. "urine Details Story Dictionary 尿 urine Heisig's Flag . . . water. Koohii #1 Animals use their urine to mark their territory. So for them, their body water works as a flag denoting their ""country"" (why bother? we all know which story you are going to pick). Koohii #2 Someone is pissing on the American flag, but since the urine is clear it looks like water. "fence Details Story Dictionary 塀 fence Heisig's Soil . . . flag . . . puzzle. Koohii #1 [fence; wall; (kokuji)] A fence separates one soil from the other. On a large scale, large pieces of soils in the world have a virtual fence called nation. Picture a world map where all countries have their soil with one color, their national flag as the legend and a fence on the borders... don´t you think it looks like a giant puzzle? Koohii #2 Why the Earth has to be fenced off and flags used to represent each ""country"" is a puzzle to me - we´re all just monkeys on a big rock spinning round the Sun! Primitives fence, soil, dirt, ground, folding screen, flag, puzzle, horns, two hands 塀(へい): wall, fence Kunyomi: Onyomi: ヘイ、ベイ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:"	"fence 塀 画数12 1136 Details Story Dictionary 塀 fence Heisig's Soil . . . flag . . . puzzle. footgear Details Story Dictionary 履 footgear Heisig's Flag . . . restore. Koohii #1 NOTE: The most common use is in はく, meaning to put on footgear, rather than actual footgear itself. STORY: You are asleep in camp when you are woken up with news that the FLAG has fallen to the enemy. You quickly PUT ON YOUR FOOTGEAR and run off to RESTORE the FLAG. Koohii #2 You should never use a flag as a shoeshine cloth to restore your footgear. Primitives footgear, flag, restore, Nelson, column, going, line, fold back, double back, reclining, lying down, sun, day, walking legs 履く(はく): to wear, to put on (lower body) 履歴(りれき): personal history, background, career, log 草履(ぞうり): sandals Kunyomi: は.く Onyomi: リ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 履く (は.く)	footgear 履 画数15 1137 Details Story Dictionary 履 footgear Heisig's Flag . . . restore. "roof Details Story Dictionary 屋 roof Heisig's Flag . . . climax. Note that this kanji has no relation to the drawing of a ""roof"" used in the primitive for house. "grip Details Story Dictionary 握 grip Heisig's Fingers . . . roof. Koohii #1 Fingers gripping the roof as your about to fall to your death. Think of an action scene in some movie. Koohii #2 (This is the にぎ of sushi). A sushi chef climaxes into a rice ball, wraps it in an American flag, and grips is firm with his fingers to form the ""Fuck You America Onigiri."". yield Details Story Dictionary 屈 yield My Story [Flag + Exit] When yielding, soldiers raise the white *flag* before *exiting* from the trenches. Koohii #1 When yielding, soldiers raise the white flag before exiting from the trenches. Koohii #2 If you live in Japan, you are only too familiar with the helpful little man who assists you in getting out of every parking lot or parking garage, standing at the exit, waving his flag to make traffic yield to you. Primitives yield, flag, exit 窮屈(きゅうくつ): narrow, tight, stiff, rigid, uneasy, formal, constrained 屈折(くっせつ): bending, indentation, refraction 理屈(りくつ): theory, reason 退屈(たいくつ): tedium, boredom Kunyomi: かが.む、かが.める Onyomi: クツ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:	yield 屈 画数8 1140 Details Story Dictionary 屈 yield My Story [Flag + Exit] When yielding, soldiers raise the white *flag* before *exiting* from the trenches. dig Details Story Dictionary 掘 dig Heisig's Fingers . . . yield. Koohii #1 If you dig with your fingers hard enough, soil eventually yields. Koohii #2 When you dig, you´d better hope that whatever you´re digging into yields to your fingers. If not, you´re bound to lose some nails. Primitives dig, finger, fingers, yield, flag, exit 採掘(さいくつ): mining 発掘(はっくつ): excavation, exhumation 掘る(ほる): dig, excavate Kunyomi: ほ.る Onyomi: クツ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 2 Compounds: 掘る (ほ.る)	dig 掘 画数11 1141 Details Story Dictionary 掘 dig Heisig's Fingers . . . yield. If not, you´re bound to lose some nails. ditch Details Story Dictionary 堀 ditch Heisig's Soil . . . yield. Koohii #1 (See dig (#1061)). When soil finally yielded thanks to your digging efforts, what you have is a ditch. Koohii #2 Ditch / trench. The yielding army abandons it´s patch of soil, leaving behind a landscape of ditchs and trenches. Trench warfare. Primitives ditch, moat, soil, dirt, ground, yield, flag, exit 堀(ほり): moat, canal Kunyomi: ほり Onyomi: クツ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 堀 (ほり)	ditch 堀 画数11 1142 Details Story Dictionary 堀 ditch Heisig's Soil . . . yield. Koohii #1 (See dig (#1061)). When soil finally yielded thanks to your digging efforts, what you have is a ditch. Koohii #2 Ditch / trench. The yielding army abandons it´s patch of soil, leaving behind a landscape of ditchs and trenches. Trench warfare. Primitives ditch, moat, soil, dirt, ground, yield, flag, exit 堀(ほり): moat, canal Kunyomi: ほり Onyomi: クツ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 堀 (ほり)
reside Details Story Dictionary 居 reside Heisig's Flag . . . old. Do not confuse with dwell (Frame 1027). Koohii #1 A humongous American flag in Florida marks the place where all the old people reside. Koohii #2 It is an old tradition that people plant a flag on places where decide to reside; this tradition still goes on: Antarctica, the moon: flags all over the place! cf. set (#1064). stratum Details Story Dictionary 層 stratum Heisig's Flag . . . increase. Koohii #1 The strata have piled up in an ever increasing pile of dirt. As the geologists go down the rocks, they flag each stratum with the name of the corresponding era. Koohii #2 Archaeologists at a dig site place small flags marking layers or strata of rock. Each of these layers was formerly the top layer. (This is not increase! Hseige keeps messing up). Primitives stratum, flag, increase, formerly, horns, rice field, brains, sun, day 階層(かいそう): class, level, stratum, hierarchy 一層(いっそう): much more, still more, all the more 高層(こうそう): upper 大層(たいそう): very much, exaggerated, very fine Kunyomi: Onyomi: ソウ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: 6 JLPT Level: 2 Compounds:	stratum 層 画数14 1146 Details Story Dictionary 層 stratum Heisig's Flag . . . increase. leak Details Story Dictionary 漏 leak Heisig's Water . . . flag . . . rain. Koohii #1 WATER always LEAKED in the spot left by the FLAG planted in the roof everytime it RAINED. Not too hard to picture a hole left in the ceiling from a flag, now leaking water. Koohii #2 Mark the holes where rain water can leak through with little flags. printing Details Story Dictionary 刷 printing Heisig's Flag . . . towel . . . saber. Koohii #1 We printed a japanese flag on his white towel by stabbing him with a saber while he was wearing it. Koohii #2 The image that keeps coming to me is of the giant mechanical printing presses. The cloth-based material is coming off the roll like a flag and then, after printing, gets cut into sheets by saber-like cutting tools. Primitives printing, flag, towel, sword, sabre, saber 刷り(すり): printing 印刷(いんさつ): printing 刷る(する): print, publish Kunyomi: す.る、-ず.り、-ずり、は.く Onyomi: サツ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: 4 JLPT Level: 2 Compounds: 刷る (す.る)	printing 刷 画数8 1150 Details Story Dictionary 刷 printing Heisig's Flag . . . towel . . . saber. "shaku Details Story Dictionary 尺 shaku Heisig's The key word shaku has actually come into English in the word shakuhachi, the ancient Japanese flute that measured ""one shaku and eight sun"" (the ""sun"" being about an inch in length). Since the shaku is about one foot in length, this makes about 20 inches. Let the final sweeping stroke be like a tape measure added to the flag. * As a primitive, this will mean the shakuhachi flute. Koohii #1 Slang for blowjob and that´s priceless for stories...but also the character looks like the letter R which I think of as standing for RULER (12 inches) other meanings include: rule, measure, length. Koohii #2 Since this is SLANG for BLOW JOB and since it looks like an ""R"", let´s have the primitive be the R in BROW JOB. :). Primitives shaku, flag, stick Kunyomi: Onyomi: シャク Lesson: 29 Jouyou: 6 JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:"	"shaku 尺 画数4 1151 Details Story Dictionary 尺 shaku Heisig's The key word shaku has actually come into English in the word shakuhachi, the ancient Japanese flute that measured ""one shaku and eight sun"" (the ""sun"" being about an inch in length). Since the shaku is about one foot in length, this makes about 20 inches. Let the final sweeping stroke be like a tape measure added to the flag. * As a primitive, this will mean the shakuhachi flute. Koohii #1 Slang for blowjob and that´s priceless for stories...but also the character looks like the letter R which I think of as standing for RULER (12 inches) other meanings include: rule, measure, length. Koohii #2 Since this is SLANG for BLOW JOB and since it looks like an ""R"", let´s have the primitive be the R in BROW JOB. :). Primitives shaku, flag, stick Kunyomi: Onyomi: シャク Lesson: 29 Jouyou: 6 JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:"

swamp Details Story Dictionary 沢 swamp Heisig's Water . . . shakuhachi. Koohii #1 You´re hiding from the enemy underwater in a swamp. To breathe, you have your shakuhachi flute poking up through the surface of the water. Koohii #2 Sirens in the swamp play eerie music on their shakuhachi flutes to lure you in - you follow the enchanting music then its too late as you get trapped in the swamp! translate Details Story Dictionary 訳 translate My Story [Say/Words + R (custom prim)] With my rad *words* and *sayings*, I radically *R*apped this whole story Koohii #1 You cannot pretend to translate into words the melody of the shakuhachi! Koohii #2 You all know that ´shakuhachi´ is a slang word for blowjob, right? In this kanji you got a job as a TRANSLATOR for Japanese porno movies. So you sit there all day translating dirty WORDS and watching girls perform SHAKUHACHI. This is the life! daytime Details Story Dictionary 昼 daytime Heisig's Shakuhachi . . . nightbreak. Koohii #1 Roosters in Japan are very civilised, they play the shakuhachi at nightbreak to signify the beginning of daytime. Koohii #2 In a Zelda game, you can warp to the daytime if you play your shakuhachi to bring about nightbreak... or your ocarina if you don´t have a shakuhachi. Primitives daytime, shaku-hachi, flag, stick, nightbreak, sun, day, one, floor 昼間(ちゅうかん): daytime, during the day 昼飯(ちゅうはん): lunch, midday meal お昼(おひる): lunch, noon 昼食(ちゅうしょく): lunch, midday meal 昼寝(ひるね): nap (at home), siesta 昼間(ひるま): daytime, during the daytime 昼休み(ひるやすみ): lunch break 昼(ひる): noon, daytime 昼御飯(ひるごはん): lunch, midday meal Kunyomi: ひる Onyomi: チュウ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: 2 JLPT Level: 4 Compounds: 昼 (ひる)	daytime 昼 画数9 1156 Details Story Dictionary 昼 daytime Heisig's Shakuhachi . . . nightbreak. "door Details Story Dictionary 戸 door Heisig's Ceiling . . . flag. Koohii #1 Traditional Japanese storefront doors have several flags, known as ""noren,"" hanging down from a curtain rod in front of them. I see this as a pseudo-pictograph, and use the horizontal line across the top to represent the curtain rod, since noren don´t usually hang from the ceiling. Koohii #2 A Japanese door has a noren, a flag hanging from a rod. (I give this primitive the meaning of a noren-covered door). Primitives door, one, flag 戸(こ): counter for houses 戸籍(こせき): census, family register 戸締り(とじまり): closing up, fastening the doors 雨戸(あまど): (sliding) storm door 井戸(いど): water well 瀬戸物(せともの): earthenware, crockery, china 戸棚(とだな): cupboard, locker, closet, wardrobe 戸(と): door (Japanese style) Kunyomi: と Onyomi: コ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: 2 JLPT Level: 2 Compounds: 戸 (と)"	"door 戸 画数4 1157 Details Story Dictionary 戸 door Heisig's Ceiling . . . flag. Koohii #1 Traditional Japanese storefront doors have several flags, known as ""noren,"" hanging down from a curtain rod in front of them. I see this as a pseudo-pictograph, and use the horizontal line across the top to represent the curtain rod, since noren don´t usually hang from the ceiling. Koohii #2 A Japanese door has a noren, a flag hanging from a rod. (I give this primitive the meaning of a noren-covered door). Primitives door, one, flag 戸(こ): counter for houses 戸籍(こせき): census, family register 戸締り(とじまり): closing up, fastening the doors 雨戸(あまど): (sliding) storm door 井戸(いど): water well 瀬戸物(せともの): earthenware, crockery, china 戸棚(とだな): cupboard, locker, closet, wardrobe 戸(と): door (Japanese style) Kunyomi: と Onyomi: コ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: 2 JLPT Level: 2 Compounds: 戸 (と)"
shoulder Details Story Dictionary 肩 shoulder My Story My Shol*DOOR* is an organ that hurts Koohii #1 The shoulder is the best part of the body to bash a door open with (Don´t ever try this. Use your foot). Koohii #2 The shoulder is part of the body you use to push through the noren in a doorway. I was having trouble with positioning of the primitives until I tweaked shaydwyrm´s story slightly. If you think of pushing through a noren, this makes sense as a pictograph. The noren hangs from above, and you push through it from below. Primitives shoulder, door, one, ceiling, flag, moon, month, flesh, part of the body 肩(かた): shoulder Kunyomi: かた Onyomi: ケン Lesson: 29 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 2 Compounds: 肩 (かた)	shoulder 肩 画数8 1158 Details Story Dictionary 肩 shoulder My Story My Shol*DOOR* is an organ that hurts Koohii #1 The shoulder is the best part of the body to bash a door open with (Don´t ever try this. Use your foot). Koohii #2 The shoulder is part of the body you use to push through the noren in a doorway. I was having trouble with positioning of the primitives until I tweaked shaydwyrm´s story slightly. If you think of pushing through a noren, this makes sense as a pictograph. The noren hangs from above, and you push through it from below. Primitives shoulder, door, one, ceiling, flag, moon, month, flesh, part of the body 肩(かた): shoulder Kunyomi: かた Onyomi: ケン Lesson: 29 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 2 Compounds: 肩 (かた)

"hearth Details Story Dictionary 炉 hearth Heisig's Hearth fire . . . door. Koohii #1 This hearth is equipped with a fire-proof door. On the kanji you can see somewhat pictographically the fire-proof door keeping the fire behind, and nothing comes under the door primitive, where you would have expected to see another primitive. Koohii #2 -""Honey? Do we have any wood left for the hearth?"" -""Aagh, just use the frickin´ door!"". "re- Details Story Dictionary 戻 re- Heisig's The key word signals a ""coming back"" or return to some place or activity. Its elements: door . . . St. Bernard dog. Koohii #1 The St. Bernard dog whining at the door of his master’s house in order to re-enter / re-turn inside. Koohii #2 Think about hachiko, the dog waiting at the door of the station, waiting for his master to re-turn. Primitives re-, door, one, ceiling, flag, large, St. Bernard 取り戻す(とりもどす): to take back, to regain 払い戻す(はらいもどす): repay, pay back 戻す(もどす): restore, put back, return 戻る(もどる): return Kunyomi: もど.す、もど.る Onyomi: レイ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 3 Compounds: 戻す (もど.す), 戻る (もど.る)"	"re- 戻 画数7 1162 Details Story Dictionary 戻 re- Heisig's The key word signals a ""coming back"" or return to some place or activity. tears Details Story Dictionary 涙 tears My Story The master shed tears of joy when his lost dog returned to his doorstep. (See {戻}) Koohii #1 I see the story of Hachiko: the faithfull dog who still waited for his master to return long after he had died. Brings a tear to the eye. Koohii #2 Tears are watery (water + re). "employ Details Story Dictionary 雇 employ Heisig's Door . . . turkey. Be sure to keep distinct from both employee (Frame 59) and use (Frame 1065). Koohii #1 Our company has no standards. We´ll employ any turkey who walks in the door. Koohii #2 Comedy. An executive is having an argument with a cocky, but skilled, employee: ""Damn it, you might be good. But that don´t account for your behavior. You keep this up and I´ll fire your ass."" ""No, you won´t."" ""What damn it, I´ll fire you your ass so fast you won´t...know...""-. ""And what will you do after you fire me, employ the next turkey that walks through that door?"" A turkey then walks through the door and hands the Exec his resume. --""The Exec employs the turkey that walked through the door"". Primitives employ, door, one, ceiling, flag, turkey 雇用(こよう): employment (long term), hire 雇う(やとう): employ, hire Kunyomi: やと.う Onyomi: コ Lesson: 29 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 2 Compounds: 雇う (やと.う)"	"employ 雇 画数12 1164 Details Story Dictionary 雇 employ Heisig's Door . . . turkey. Koohii #2 The people we employ are always turning their heads to look back. They don´t want to be caught playing solitare on company time. show Details Story Dictionary 示 show Heisig's Although the elements two and little are available for the using, it may be easier to remember this character as a picture of an altar. Something placed atop the altar is put on show for all to see. * As a primitive, this kanji means altar. At the left, the abbreviated form that this element takes is made by chopping the altar in half and leaving only one dot behind to represent the right side. The new appearance of this primitive form, ネ, should be kept distinct from that for cloak, identical except for the one final short stroke. Koohii #1 A boy made an altar, but he´s afraid to show it to God because he thinks it´s two little. Koohii #2 I´ll SHOW you mine if you show me yours!, she said. I did & she scoffed because it was TWO LITTLE. Primitives show, altar, show, two, small 暗示(あんじ): hint, suggestion 指示(しじ): indication, instruction, directions 提示(ていじ): presentation, exhibit, suggest, citation 展示(てんじ): exhibition, display 掲示(けいじ): notice, bulletin 示す(しめす): show, indicate, denote, point out Kunyomi: しめ.す Onyomi: ジ、シ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 5 JLPT Level: 3 Compounds: 示威 (しい), 示談 (じだん), 指示 (しじ), 示す (しめ.す)	show 示 画数5 1167 Details Story Dictionary 示 show Heisig's Although the elements two and little are available for the using, it may be easier to remember this character as a picture of an altar. At the left, the abbreviated form that this element takes is made by chopping the altar in half and leaving only one dot behind to represent the right side. The new appearance of this primitive form, ネ, should be kept distinct from that for cloak, identical except for the one final short stroke. Koohii #1 A boy made an altar, but he´s afraid to show it to God because he thinks it´s two little. Koohii #2 I´ll SHOW you mine if you show me yours!, she said. I did & she scoffed because it was TWO LITTLE. salutation Details Story Dictionary 礼 salutation Heisig's This key word refers to the polite bows and ceremonious forms of salutation so important in Japanese culture. Its elements: altar . . . fishhook. Koohii #1 Indy, my friend, you must be very careful! If you approach the altar and do not give the proper salutation a large fishhook will rip you away. Koohii #2 You should fish hook (bend/bow) your body before an altar as a form of salutation to God/gods. Primitives salute, salutation, altar, fishhook 無礼(ぶれい): impolite, rude 礼(れい): expression of gratitude 礼儀(れいぎ): manners, courtesy, etiquette お礼(おれい): courtesy Kunyomi: Onyomi: レイ、ライ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 3 JLPT Level: 3 Compounds: 礼儀 (れいぎ), 謝礼 (しゃれい), 無礼 (ぶれい)	salutation 礼 画数5 1168 Details Story Dictionary 礼 salutation Heisig's This key word refers to the polite bows and ceremonious forms of salutation so important in Japanese culture. Koohii #2 You should fish hook (bend/bow) your body before an altar as a form of salutation to God/gods. Primitives salute, salutation, altar, fishhook 無礼(ぶれい): impolite, rude 礼(れい): expression of gratitude 礼儀(れいぎ): manners, courtesy, etiquette お礼(おれい): courtesy Kunyomi: Onyomi: レイ、ライ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 3 JLPT Level: 3 Compounds: 礼儀 (れいぎ), 謝礼 (しゃれい), 無礼 (ぶれい)
auspicious Details Story Dictionary 祥 auspicious Heisig's Altar . . . sheep. Koohii #1 Bringing a sheep to sacrifice on the altar was a sign of an auspicious life. The poor could only afford a pigeon, the more auspicious an expensive sheep for an offering. Koohii #2 On this ewe-spicious occasion, you sacrifice a sheep at the altar. —— Sorry, but I really need more than generic altar sacrifices to connect keywords to stories. Sometimes an egregious pun is the only way. Primitives auspicious, altar, sheep Kunyomi: さいわ.い、きざ.し、よ.い、つまび.らか Onyomi: ショウ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:	auspicious 祥 画数10 1169 Details Story Dictionary 祥 auspicious Heisig's Altar . . . sheep. celebrate Details Story Dictionary 祝 celebrate My Story [ネ + older bro {兄}] We shouldnt celebrate the *ネcrophile's* birthday without his *older bro* Koohii #1 It´s a Bar Mitzvah. At the altar, the teenager is singing in his awful, mid-puberty voice. We´ll all celebrate when that part is over! Koohii #2 When Japanese people turn 20 they usually visit the altar at their local shrine and celebrate no longer being a teenager. Primitives celebrate, altar, elder brother, teenager, mouth, human legs 祝賀(しゅくが): celebration, congratulations 祝い(いわい): celebration, festival 祝う(いわう): congratulate, celebrate 祝日(しゅくじつ): national holiday お祝い(おいわい): celebration Kunyomi: いわ.う Onyomi: シュク、シュウ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 4 JLPT Level: 2 Compounds: 祝賀 (しゅくが), 祝日 (しゅくじつ), 慶祝 (けいしゅく), 祝う (いわ.う)	celebrate 祝 画数9 1170 Details Story Dictionary 祝 celebrate My Story [ネ + older bro {兄}] We shouldnt celebrate the *ネcrophile's* birthday without his *older bro* Koohii #1 It´s a Bar Mitzvah. blessing Details Story Dictionary 福 blessing Heisig's Altar . . . wealth. Koohii #1 This recalls the selling of indulgences in the history of the Church (As an aside, Protestantism began as a protest of this practice). Basically, one gave wealth to the altar (i.e. priest) and received a blessing. If you prefer a Jewish version, think of the donation (wealth) that is expected when you´re called to the ark (altar in the kanji) to give a blessing over the torah. Koohii #2 Put all your wealth on the church altar and receive one blessing. (You stand up out of your wheelchair or something.). Primitives blessing, altar, wealth, one, ceiling, mouth, rice field, brains 福(ふく): good fortune 福祉(ふくし): welfare, well-being 幸福(こうふく): happiness, blessedness Kunyomi: Onyomi: フク Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 3 JLPT Level: 3 Compounds:	blessing 福 画数13 1171 Details Story Dictionary 福 blessing Heisig's Altar . . . wealth. Koohii #1 This recalls the selling of indulgences in the history of the Church (As an aside, Protestantism began as a protest of this practice). Basically, one gave wealth to the altar (i.e. priest) and received a blessing. If you prefer a Jewish version, think of the donation (wealth) that is expected when you´re called to the ark (altar in the kanji) to give a blessing over the torah. Koohii #2 Put all your wealth on the church altar and receive one blessing. (You stand up out of your wheelchair or something.). company Details Story Dictionary 社 company My Story [ネ + Jesus] The catholic church is a company full of *necorphiles* and *Jesus*-loving dudes Koohii #1 When you enter a Japanese company it´s like you join a cult... your workdesk becomes your altar and you worship the very soil the office is built on. Koohii #2 Some Japanese companies, including Toyota, have a Shinto shrine on their grounds to bring luck and prosperity to the company and its employees. Primitives company, altar, soil, dirt, ground 社交(しゃこう): social life, social intercourse 社宅(しゃたく): company owned house 出社(しゅっしゃ): arrival (in a country at work etc.) 社(やしろ): Shinto shrine 社会科学(しゃかいかがく): social science 社説(しゃせつ): editorial, leading article 商社(しょうしゃ): trading company, firm 入社(にゅうしゃ): entry to a company 社会(しゃかい): society 社長(しゃちょう): president 神社(じんじゃ): Shinto shrine 新聞社(しんぶんしゃ): newspaper office 会社(かいしゃ): company, corporation Kunyomi: やしろ Onyomi: シャ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 2 JLPT Level: 4 Compounds: 社 (やしろ)	company 社 画数7 1173 Details Story Dictionary 社 company My Story [ネ + Jesus] The catholic church is a company full of *necorphiles* and *Jesus*-loving dudes Koohii #1 When you enter a Japanese company it´s like you join a cult... your workdesk becomes your altar and you worship the very soil the office is built on. Koohii #2 Some Japanese companies, including Toyota, have a Shinto shrine on their grounds to bring luck and prosperity to the company and its employees. "inspection Details Story Dictionary 視 inspection Heisig's Altar . . . see. Koohii #1 The beaurocracy in Japan is such that even altars need to be inspection approved. A little man with glasses comes once a year to give the altar a ""visual once over"" as he calls it (perhaps checking for unauthorised symbology?). Koohii #2 [inspection; regard as; see; look at] Inspection: you 示 show (#1086) and someone else 見 see (#57). Primitives inspection, altar, see, telescope, eye, human legs 監視(かんし): observation, guarding, inspection, surveillance 近視(きんし): shortsightedness 視覚(しかく): sense of sight, vision 視察(しさつ): inspection, observation 視点(してん): opinion, point of view, visual point 視野(しや): field of vision, outlook 重視(じゅうし): importance, stress, serious consideration 無視(むし): disregard, ignore Kunyomi: み.る Onyomi: シ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 6 JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:"	"inspection 視 画数11 1174 Details Story Dictionary 視 inspection Heisig's Altar . . . see. Primitives inspection, altar, see, telescope, eye, human legs 監視(かんし): observation, guarding, inspection, surveillance 近視(きんし): shortsightedness 視覚(しかく): sense of sight, vision 視察(しさつ): inspection, observation 視点(してん): opinion, point of view, visual point 視野(しや): field of vision, outlook 重視(じゅうし): importance, stress, serious consideration 無視(むし): disregard, ignore Kunyomi: み.る Onyomi: シ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 6 JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:"
Nara Details Story Dictionary 奈 Nara Heisig's We choose the city of Nara as the key word in this case because this kanji, frequently used in proper names, appears in Nara; and also because of Nara's famed religious monuments, which help us with the primitives: St. Bernard dog . . . altar. Koohii #1 It´s beautiful place, but the dark side of Nara is that they sacrifice St. Bernards on evil altars every night after the tourists leave! Koohii #2 Nara is just a big show for tourists. Primitives nara, large, St. Bernard, altar, show, two, small Kunyomi: いかん、からなし Onyomi: ナ、ナイ、ダイ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:	Nara 奈 画数8 1175 Details Story Dictionary 奈 Nara Heisig's We choose the city of Nara as the key word in this case because this kanji, frequently used in proper names, appears in Nara; and also because of Nara's famed religious monuments, which help us with the primitives: St. Bernard dog . . . altar. military officer Details Story Dictionary 尉 military officer My Story [Flag + Altar + glue] The *flag* and the *altar* were glued by the military officer Koohii #1 Of course it had to be the military officer´s idea to glue a national flag to the altar he´s stationed at. Koohii #2 Perhaps you have heard about Koizumis controversial visits at the Yasukuni war memorial shrine. It is the japanese flag waving above a small stone altar. A military officer keeps watch here night and day, to honor the dead war heroes, as if he is glued to the ground. Primitives military officer, flag, altar, show, two, small, glue 尉(じょう): jailer, old man, rank, company officer Kunyomi: Onyomi: イ、ジョウ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:	military officer 尉 画数11 1176 Details Story Dictionary 尉 military officer My Story [Flag + Altar + glue] The *flag* and the *altar* were glued by the military officer Koohii #1 Of course it had to be the military officer´s idea to glue a national flag to the altar he´s stationed at. "consolation Details Story Dictionary 慰 consolation My Story [Military Officer {尉} + Heart] A *military officer* must offer consolation to the *hearts* of the families of his fallen men. Koohii #1 A military officer must offer consolation to the hearts of the families of his fallen men. Koohii #2 This Kanji appears in the word 慰安婦 いあんふ, which was what the infamous WW II ""comfort women"" were called in Japanese. The story goes something like this: As a way of providing consolation to battle-weary, heartsick military officers and soldiers, the Japanese set up comfort stations (brothels) for their servicemen. (Just to be clear: this is not an endorsement of the practice, just a way to remember the Kanji.). Primitives consolation, military officer, flag, altar, show, two, small, glue, heart 慰める(なぐさめる): comfort, console Kunyomi: なぐさ.める、なぐさ.む Onyomi: イ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 慰む (なぐさ.む), 慰める (なぐさ.める)"	"consolation 慰 画数15 1177 Details Story Dictionary 慰 consolation My Story [Military Officer {尉} + Heart] A *military officer* must offer consolation to the *hearts* of the families of his fallen men. goodwill Details Story Dictionary 款 goodwill Heisig's Samurai . . . altar . . . yawning. Koohii #1 Samuari, altar, yawn The samurai is on the altar, preaching about goodwill. The audience just yawns however, they want to see the man fight! Koohii #2 For better remembering the placement of the eleements: The samurai kneels before the altar at his wedding ceremony, when some of the attendants lets out a big yawn. He is a kind man and for the day his goodwill benefits everyone. No beheadings. "prohibition Details Story Dictionary 禁 prohibition Heisig's Grove . . . altar. Koohii #1 Similar to radical tyro´s story. If you live in Japan, your main exposure to this kanji is probably ""no smoking"" signs. So I imagine the government enacting a prohibition of tobacco, and burning whole groves of tobacco plants on an altar (the altar of public health, or self-righteousness, if you will). Koohii #2 Hidden in a grove was a church with a secret altar that was stocked full of prohibited alcohol during the American prohibition period of 1920-1933. A local registered himself as a mininster of this altar so he could stock prohibited alcohol ""for sacremental purposes"" and share it with his kin (きん). Primitives prohibition, grove, tree, wood, altar, show, two, small, tree2, wood2 禁じる(きんじる): to prohibit 禁ずる(きんずる): to forbid, to suppress 禁物(きんもつ): taboo, forbidden thing 禁煙(きんえん): No Smoking! 禁止(きんし): prohibition, ban Kunyomi: Onyomi: キン Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 5 JLPT Level: 2 Compounds:"	"prohibition 禁 画数13 1179 Details Story Dictionary 禁 prohibition Heisig's Grove . . . altar. ritual Details Story Dictionary 祭 ritual Heisig's Flesh . . . crotch . . . altar. Note how the second element is cut short, giving a tent-like effect to the character. Koohii #1 A ritual such as a circumcision: a small piece of flesh from the crotch is left on the altar. Koohii #2 There are many famous penis matsuris(festivals) in Japan. The rituals of these festivals involve placing the flesh of the crotch on an altar. Primitives ritual, moon, month, flesh, part of the body, crotch, altar, show, two, small 祭日(さいじつ): national holiday, festival day 祭(まつり): festival, feast 祭る(まつる): deify, enshrine お祭り(おまつり): festival Kunyomi: まつ.る、まつ.り、まつり Onyomi: サイ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 3 JLPT Level: 2 Compounds: 祭り (まつ.り), 祭る (まつ.る)	ritual 祭 画数11 1183 Details Story Dictionary 祭 ritual Heisig's Flesh . . . crotch . . . altar. "wherefore Details Story Dictionary 由 wherefore Heisig's The ""wherefore"" of this kanji explains the reason or origin of a thing. It does this graphically by depicting a seed in a rice field sending up a single sprout, which is the whole why and wherefore of the seed's falling in the earth and dying. (When the flower appears, you will recall from frame 249, we have a full seedling.) * As a primitive, in conformity to the explanation above, this kanji will be taken to mean shoot or sprout. Koohii #1 Wherefore art thou, Sprouteo? (Juliet has fallen in love with a brussel sprout) (OR: A brussel sprout has fallen from Juliet´s dinner plate and rolled off). Koohii #2 Cogito ergo sum. Wherefore is a bad choice here for two reasons. For one, it´s often mistranslated as ""where"" when in fact it´s an urge to know a cause or reason; and two, because this kanji represents the reason, not the urge. [A thought sprouts from my brain. I think, therefore I am.]. Primitives wherefore, sprout, shoot 経由(けいゆ): go by the way, via 不自由(ふじゆう): discomfort, disability, inconvenience, destitution 自由(じゆう): freedom 理由(りゆう): reason Kunyomi: よし、よ.る Onyomi: ユ、ユウ、ユイ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 3 JLPT Level: 3 Compounds: 由来 (ゆらい), 経由 (けいゆ), 自由 (じゆう), 理由 (りゆう), 事由 (じゆう), 由 (よし)"	"wherefore 由 画数5 1186 Details Story Dictionary 由 wherefore Heisig's The ""wherefore"" of this kanji explains the reason or origin of a thing. It does this graphically by depicting a seed in a rice field sending up a single sprout, which is the whole why and wherefore of the seed's falling in the earth and dying. (When the flower appears, you will recall from frame 249, we have a full seedling.) * As a primitive, in conformity to the explanation above, this kanji will be taken to mean shoot or sprout. Koohii #1 Wherefore art thou, Sprouteo? (Juliet has fallen in love with a brussel sprout) (OR: A brussel sprout has fallen from Juliet´s dinner plate and rolled off). Koohii #2 Cogito ergo sum. Wherefore is a bad choice here for two reasons. For one, it´s often mistranslated as ""where"" when in fact it´s an urge to know a cause or reason; and two, because this kanji represents the reason, not the urge. [A thought sprouts from my brain. I think, therefore I am.]. Primitives wherefore, sprout, shoot 経由(けいゆ): go by the way, via 不自由(ふじゆう): discomfort, disability, inconvenience, destitution 自由(じゆう): freedom 理由(りゆう): reason Kunyomi: よし、よ.る Onyomi: ユ、ユウ、ユイ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 3 JLPT Level: 3 Compounds: 由来 (ゆらい), 経由 (けいゆ), 自由 (じゆう), 理由 (りゆう), 事由 (じゆう), 由 (よし)"
pluck Details Story Dictionary 抽 pluck Heisig's Fingers . . . sprout. Koohii #1 [When I see the word pluck, I think eyebrows, not vegetables. So, to avoid confusing with pick (#733):] Each time this singular, long, wiry black hair starts to sprout out of my chin again, I pluck it with my fingers. Koohii #2 If you pluck your fingers, new ones will sprout in their place. (try it ;). Koohii #2 In a rather surprising scientific breakthrough, genetically modified Brussel sprouts (which have become extremely absorbative), are thrown in the water to suck up oil spills. "mid-air / space (outer space) Details Story Dictionary 宙 mid-air / space (outer space) My Story [Crown + freedom/reason {由}] In space, everyone can *crown* themselves *freely* as King of Space Koohii #1 Jack´s beanstalk sprouted up, pushed at the roof and lifted the house so that it hangs in mid-air suspended on the SPROUT. Koohii #2 Hahaha, the image of walking into a house and finding a sea of brussel sprouts floating mid-air is enough for me to remember. Maybe there´s a magician in the kitchen shouting a reassuring ""Don´t mind the sprouts!"". deliver Details Story Dictionary 届 deliver Heisig's Flag . . . sprout. Koohii #1 In the US, when the mail is delivered, a flag sprouts up on your mailbox. (We don´t have that in Australia.). Koohii #2 A Japanese man ordered some Brussel sprouts from Belgium. They are delivered with a little Belgian flag (as seen sometimes in shops, little flags indicating the provenance and authenticity of the food like cheese and meat). Primitives deliver, flag, sprout, shoot 届け(とどけ): report, notification, registration 届く(とどく): reach 届ける(とどける): deliver Kunyomi: とど.ける、-とど.け、とど.く Onyomi: カイ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 6 JLPT Level: 2 Compounds: 届く (とど.く), 届ける (とど.ける)	deliver 届 画数8 1191 Details Story Dictionary 届 deliver Heisig's Flag . . . sprout. Koohii #1 In the US, when the mail is delivered, a flag sprouts up on your mailbox. (We don´t have that in Australia.). Koohii #2 A Japanese man ordered some Brussel sprouts from Belgium. They are delivered with a little Belgian flag (as seen sometimes in shops, little flags indicating the provenance and authenticity of the food like cheese and meat). flute Details Story Dictionary 笛 flute Heisig's Bamboo . . . sprout. Koohii #1 Flute is made of bamboo sprout. Koohii #2 You pick up your bamboo flute, and recoil in shock as out comes not the dulcet melody you had hoped to play, but rather a Brussels sprout! You play again, and again a Brussels sprout. A bamboo flute that plays sprouts! Fabulous! Puts that golden egg laying goose in its place. Primitives flute, bamboo, sprout, shoot 笛(ふえ): flute Kunyomi: ふえ Onyomi: テキ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 3 JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 笛 (ふえ)	flute 笛 画数11 1192 Details Story Dictionary 笛 flute Heisig's Bamboo . . . sprout. axis Details Story Dictionary 軸 axis Heisig's Car . . . shoot. Koohii #1 The Germans manufactured so many cars during World War II that it was almost as if they were sprouting from the factories of the Axis. Koohii #2 An absurd image, but what the heck - worked for me. Imagine a car going across a plain at a fast speed. Suddenly a single sprout (the only one to be seen) gets stuck to the car´s wheels, causing the car to fly around its axis. Primitives axis, car, sprout, shoot 軸(じく): axis, stem, shaft, axle Kunyomi: Onyomi: ジク Lesson: 30 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds:	axis 軸 画数12 1193 Details Story Dictionary 軸 axis Heisig's Car . . . shoot. "armor Details Story Dictionary 甲 armor Heisig's This kanji reverses the element for sprout, giving the image of roots being sent down into the earth by a seed planted in the rice field. From there you must invent a connection to the keyword, armor. * The primitive meaning is roots. Important to that word is the image of ""pushing downwards,"" as roots do. Koohii #1 Funny.. this appeared to me as a pictograph of a samurai´s armor. Then I looked up images of the samurai armor and it is not even remotely similar. Then I realised it looks in fact like the belly of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which I somehow associated with the samurai armor because of the ""turtle samurai"" that appeared earlier. Fits me. The bit that pokes down is to protect the genitals, I guess. Koohii #2 It looks like a bird´s eye view of a tank (modern armor). Primitives armour, armor, roots 甲(きのえ): 1st in rank, first sign of the Chinese calendar, shell, instep, grade A Kunyomi: きのえ Onyomi: コウ、カン、カ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 甲乙 (こうおつ), 装甲車 (そうこうしゃ)"	"armor 甲 画数5 1194 Details Story Dictionary 甲 armor Heisig's This kanji reverses the element for sprout, giving the image of roots being sent down into the earth by a seed planted in the rice field. From there you must invent a connection to the keyword, armor. * The primitive meaning is roots. Important to that word is the image of ""pushing downwards,"" as roots do. Then I realised it looks in fact like the belly of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which I somehow associated with the samurai armor because of the ""turtle samurai"" that appeared earlier. push Details Story Dictionary 押 push My Story [ #push# = *My Nigga MO* + *turtle shell*] = *My Nigga MO* kept pushing the damn *turtle shell*, like some button. [ push = fingers + roots ]　Moe, using his fingers, pushed the root down Koohii #1 Push the roots down, instead of plucking the seedling. Koohii #2 Use your fingers to make sure the roots of your plant are deep underground by pushing them down, down, down. Primitives push, finger, fingers, armour, armor, roots 押さえる(おさえる): to stop, to restrain, to seize, to repress, to suppress, to press down 押し込む(おしこむ): to push into, to crowd into 押し寄せる(おしよせる): to push aside, to advance on 押える(おさえる): stop, restrain, seize, repress, suppress, press down 押し入れ(おしいれ): closet 押す(おす): push, press, stamp (e.g. a passport) Kunyomi: お.す、お.し-、お.っ-、お.さえる、おさ.える Onyomi: オウ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 3 Compounds: 押さえる (お.さえる), 押す (お.す)	push 押 画数8 1195 Details Story Dictionary 押 push My Story [ #push# = *My Nigga MO* + *turtle shell*] = *My Nigga MO* kept pushing the damn *turtle shell*, like some button. headland Details Story Dictionary 岬 headland Heisig's Like the cape (Frame 164) and the promontory (Frame 840), the headland refers to a jut of land. Its elements: mountain . . . roots. Koohii #1 A headland is a mountain that is firmly rooted despite being surrounded on 3 sides by water. (Just like your head is a mountain surrounded by air on 3 sides, a headland!). Koohii #2 Headlands are natural forts; in fact, once men build castles on them, they become armoured mountains. (Gibralter, for example, is basically an armoured mountain). Primitives headland, mountain, armour, armor, roots 岬(みさき): cape (on coast) Kunyomi: みさき Onyomi: コウ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 岬 (みさき)	headland 岬 画数8 1196 Details Story Dictionary 岬 headland Heisig's Like the cape (Frame 164) and the promontory (Frame 840), the headland refers to a jut of land. Its elements: mountain . . . roots. Koohii #1 A headland is a mountain that is firmly rooted despite being surrounded on 3 sides by water. (Just like your head is a mountain surrounded by air on 3 sides, a headland!). Koohii #2 Headlands are natural forts; in fact, once men build castles on them, they become armoured mountains. (Gibralter, for example, is basically an armoured mountain). Primitives headland, mountain, armour, armor, roots 岬(みさき): cape (on coast) Kunyomi: みさき Onyomi: コウ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 岬 (みさき)
insert Details Story Dictionary 挿 insert Heisig's Fingers . . . thousand . . . roots. Observe how the writing order does not follow the elements in order, because the final stroke is used for two different elements. Koohii #1 A rice farmer´s delicate fingers have inserted 1,000 rooted seedlings into his field. Koohii #2 Imagine a crazy japanese hentai: multiple fingers and thousand of root-like tentacles are inserting themselves in... well, I think you can fill the rest. Primitives insert, finger, fingers, thousand, armour, armor, roots 挿す(さす): to insert, put in, graft Kunyomi: さ.す、はさ.む Onyomi: ソウ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 挿す (さ.す)	insert 挿 画数10 1197 Details Story Dictionary 挿 insert Heisig's Fingers . . . thousand . . . roots. Koohii #1 A rice farmer´s delicate fingers have inserted 1,000 rooted seedlings into his field. Koohii #2 Imagine a crazy japanese hentai: multiple fingers and thousand of root-like tentacles are inserting themselves in... well, I think you can fill the rest. "speaketh Details Story Dictionary 申 speaketh Heisig's The olde English is used here to indicate a humble form of the third person singular of the verb ""to speak."" It is written by a tongue wagging in the mouth with a walking stick rammed through it and coming out at both ends. * While this kanji has obvious affinities to the ""seed"" group, it also happens to be the zodiacal sign of the monkey (the one who speaketh no evil, among other things). We shall therefore take monkey as its primitive meaning. Koohii #1 I imagine thomeone who can not pronounth the ""s"" and speaketh like thith becauth they have a cane in their mouth. Koohii #2 I had persistent trouble confusing this one with 曰 sayeth (#578). The way I keep it sorted out is that this one is used in ""moshi moshi"" when answering the phone, similar to the way an American would say ""hello, this is X speaking."". Primitives speaketh, monkey, sun, day, stick 申告(しんこく): report, statement, filing a return, notification 申し入れる(もうしいれる): to propose, to suggest 申し込み(もうしこみ): application, entry, request, subscription, offer, proposal, overture, challenge 申出(もうしで): proposal, request, claim, report, notice 申し出る(もうしでる): to report to, to tell, to suggest, to submit, to request, to make an offer, to come forward with information 申し分(もうしぶん): objection, shortcomings 申請(しんせい): application, request, petition 申し込む(もうしこむ): apply for, propose, offer, challenge, request 申し訳(もうしわけ): apology, excuse 申し訳ない(もうしわけない): inexcusable 申し上げる(もうしあげる): say (polite) 申す(もうす): say (polite) Kunyomi: もう.す、もう.し-、さる Onyomi: シン Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 3 JLPT Level: 3 Compounds: 申す (もう.す)"	"speaketh 申 画数5 1198 Details Story Dictionary 申 speaketh Heisig's The olde English is used here to indicate a humble form of the third person singular of the verb ""to speak."" Koohii #2 Hinduism has many gods, not just one God. One of the most famous of these gods is Hanuman the monkey. Many altars are dedicated to him. search Details Story Dictionary 捜 search Heisig's Fingers . . . monkey . . . crotch. Koohii #1 The monkey searches around with his fingers for his crotch. Koohii #2 If you are familiar with the Monkey legends (西遊記 Journey to the West) there is a good image for this character: While searching for the end of the universe, monkey reaches to his crotch and urinates on Buddha´s fingers. (Update: new link http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RYXFppaKLL4). Koohii #1 If only Eve had used her brains and not taken the forbidden fruit from the tree. Koohii #2 Eve ate fruit from the tree and knowledge filled her brain.…　　　　　　RTK2:　カ　果汁　かじゅう (fruit juice)…　　　　　　　　　　　　　　Semi-Pure Group:　菓1122　課1123　(ﾗ): 裸1124. Primitives fruit, rice field, brains, tree, wood 成果(せいか): results, fruits 果ない(はかない): fleeting, transient, short-lived, momentary, vain, fickle, miserable, empty, ephemeral 果たして(はたして): as was expected, really 果たす(はたす): to accomplish, to fulfill, to carry out, to achieve 果て(はて): the end, the extremity, the limit(s), the result 果てる(はてる): to end, to be finished, to be exhausted, to die, to perish 果実(かじつ): fruit, nut, berry 結果(けっか): result, consequence 効果(こうか): effect, effectiveness, efficacy, result 果物(くだもの): fruit Kunyomi: は.たす、はた.す、-は.たす、は.てる、-は.てる、は.て Onyomi: カ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 4 JLPT Level: 3 Compounds: 果たす (は.たす), 果て (は.て), 果てる (は.てる)	fruit / result 果 画数8 1202 Details Story Dictionary 果 fruit / result My Story [rice field + Tree] In the *rice field*, I saw a *tree* with fruits on it. "chapter Details Story Dictionary 課 chapter Heisig's Words . . . fruit. Koohii #1 After I finish each chapter of RTK, I eat a piece of fruit to celebrate all the new words I´ve learned. (Thanks Misha!). Koohii #2 Words signify the written words in a book. The fruit represents something whole, complete. A chapter in a book often offers a complete idea, setting, or account. It´s good to disambiguate the keyword from paragraph (#82). To reinforce the kanji, imagine eating a fruit at the end of each chapter of Tolstoy´s ""War and Peace"" to reward yourself. (If you ate a fruit at the end of each paragraph, you´d very quickly run out of fruit). Primitives chapter, say, words, keitai, mouth, fruit, rice field, brains, tree, wood 課外(かがい): extracurricular 課題(かだい): subject, theme, task 課(か): counter for chapters (of a book) 課税(かぜい): taxation 課程(かてい): course, curriculum 日課(にっか): daily lesson, daily work, daily routine Kunyomi: Onyomi: カ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 4 JLPT Level: 2 Compounds:"	"chapter 課 画数15 1204 Details Story Dictionary 課 chapter Heisig's Words . . . fruit. Koohii #1 After I finish each chapter of RTK, I eat a piece of fruit to celebrate all the new words I´ve learned. (Thanks Misha!). Koohii #2 Words signify the written words in a book. The fruit represents something whole, complete. A chapter in a book often offers a complete idea, setting, or account. It´s good to disambiguate the keyword from paragraph (#82). To reinforce the kanji, imagine eating a fruit at the end of each chapter of Tolstoy´s ""War and Peace"" to reward yourself. (If you ate a fruit at the end of each paragraph, you´d very quickly run out of fruit). Primitives chapter, say, words, keitai, mouth, fruit, rice field, brains, tree, wood 課外(かがい): extracurricular 課題(かだい): subject, theme, task 課(か): counter for chapters (of a book) 課税(かぜい): taxation 課程(かてい): course, curriculum 日課(にっか): daily lesson, daily work, daily routine Kunyomi: Onyomi: カ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: 4 JLPT Level: 2 Compounds:"
naked Details Story Dictionary 裸 naked Heisig's Cloak . . . fruit. Koohii #1 Here we have Adam and Eve eating of the forbidden fruit and realizing they were naked, and so clothing themselves in a cloak. Koohii #2 Hey honey, I´m naked underneath this cloak. I´ve got some nice melons and a fresh peach waiting for you. Don´t you want to taste my forbidden fruits...? Primitives naked, cloak, fruit, rice field, brains, tree, wood 裸足(はだし): barefoot 裸(はだか): naked, nude, bare Kunyomi: はだか Onyomi: ラ Lesson: 30 Jouyou: JH JLPT Level: 1 Compounds: 裸 (はだか)	naked 裸 画数13 1205 Details Story Dictionary 裸 naked Heisig's Cloak . . . fruit.
